children.subject: I want these to be public too and I don't disagree with you, expect with the word everyone. Not everyone is able to consume these lectures, which is precisely the problem. :(

Just to put my opinion out there in a broader sense, I think that it's incredibly stupid for these videos to be taken down. Even if the captioning is not up to code, it helps absolutely no one for everything to be taken down. Before I transferred into this school (I went to a community college), I watched Jonathan Shewchuk entire 61B series (which is available for public consumption on the school's YouTube channel). I learned a lot, and not just about computer science. That lecture series is world class, and it inspired me to try and reach my potential. It was the first glimpse I had at the beauty of computer science and the ideas behind it.

Why should the public be denied something which can be delivered at zero cost to the university? It's already there. Not everyone can come to Cal, but everyone should have the choice to watch the lectures (captions or no). 

P.S.

Mad respect to DeNero and Hug for making their textbooks and lectures freely available to the public by circumventing the the formal university channels.

To the best of my (outsider and limited) understanding, the videos are being taken down because a DoJ investigation determined that the quality of captions were not up to code with the ADA. The school is left with the choice of hiring someone to recaption all of the videos, or to take them down.

In my view, this is a poor justification to remove public access.

I completely agree. The US government should not have the right to force a educational institution, even if it is public, to provide captions for all their videos. While the objective is good, it's bad policy and results in fewer videos for everyone.

What do you think of my idea?
If students were to post the videos on their personal channels, that wouldn't be subjected to the DoJ decision, so why not just open it up to public.

But it could potentially violate copyright law. Not that I expect professors to care, and the university would be daft to go after students, but I would do a bit of reading before making them public. :)

What if we all crowd sourced the lecture links? All of us students would post all our past EECS webcast links on a Google Doc, which is only accessible to Berkeley students. I want to make it public but I have respect for our webcasting staff and don't want to circumvent them if they have a valid reason for taking down the videos.

Please let me know below if you're interested. If so, I will start the Google Doc and add my webcasts onto it.

history.content: The justification that videos must be removed because does not meet ADA specifications on captioning is unequivocally most ridiculous and illogical justification I have ever heard in my life. Improving captioning for disabled students is a worthy goal, and a worthy goal for improving our society. But removing access to these videos is an objective detriment to public education. This logic is equivalent to saying "Because not everyone can have it, no one can." I'm incredibly disappointed by this decision (and I know this decision was forced upon the university by the government). I would love to hear someone who supports this decision's opinions, including their justifications for it. Because I have tried very hard to see what benefit there is to society by removing public access to these videos, and I cannot come up with any.

children.subject:
Forgot to finish first paragraph!

...If the viewer is a American citizen, they will appreciate Berkeley more so if they see "cut funding to public universities on their ballot" they will likely vote no. Rather than it being some ivy tower institution where violent protests happen every few months, it will be a "I love Berkeley, they are the reason I studied CS in college and am working at Google, they have protests but on the whole Berkeley is one of the world's greatest educational institutions". Not to mention the increased donations from the public.

If the viewer is not an American institution, they will respect Berkeley as a university. You go to any other country in the world and ask them to list the top universities in the world and they'll say "Harvard, MIT, Stanford, etc" Why? Because the sons and daughters of their Presidents went to those schools. Their country's richest men went to those schools. When they see a university on TV, it's one of those schools.

Prestige is based on how ordinary people think of a school. And it's something we can EASILY boost by posting our videos online. People know us because we have dozens of Nobel winners, we discovered Berkelium, created UNIX/iPython/etc. Let's not go backwards.

The issue is more of the DOJ forcing it upon Berkeley in the first place. 

If the argument is that DSP students are not being properly accommodated as they are taking the course, then appropriate action should be taken to ensure a fair learning experience for everyone, and if that were in the form of better captions, then UC Berkeley should take steps to caption their webcasts. But if that was the case, then removing the videos from the public wouldn't change anything. 

Unfortunately, the argument here is that because there exists a subset of the world's population, not UC Berkeley students, but people in general, that cannot access to these videos, then they must be removed. I strongly disagree with the notion that an institution that doesn't HAVE to make public webcasts should be FORCED to make them accessible to everyone. We can recognize that there is a problem here; that the captioning isn't up to par for every person on this planet. But the solution is not to deny everyone to these videos.

In addition to what the above Anon is driving at, I think that the school's response (something along the lines of, "it would cost a lot of money to recaption hundreds of hours of footage, money that should go to something more pressing") was appropriate, and that this is an embarrassing example of federal overreach creating a negative sum game.

If institutions are never forced to provide accessible services, what incentives do they have to do so?

To be clear, I'm not a fan of the DOJs stance on this one, but so far the only answers I can come up with for the above question are worrisome. :(

OP Here. Adding to the follow up, publishing webcasts publically doesn't just enable people to watch some videos. It's more than that. These people start to love Berkeley. If the viewer is a American citizen

MIT and Stanford don't post all their videos online for their students. They post them so their professors can be recognized as the world's experts in their fields. When I think of "iOS Programming", I think of Paul Hegarty, because he taught me. Meanwhile, we have some of the greatest Professors in the world, from Prof. Sahai to Prof. Michael Jordan, people who could be recognized globally for educating the next generation of machine learning researchers. Yet our university doesn't consider any of that. We as a university need to start looking at the big picture and not just say "only our students are allowed." 

To be honest, I think they are taking down all the videos out of laziness. I hate to say this but you and I can both guess what happened. The DOJ said Berkeley had to provide captions so the webcast people thought, "Hey, we already made all the current webcasts private with no problems, why not remove them all?" It's easier than just removing the videos, which is their job, than thinking "how does this affect students", which requires effort and a desire to go above and beyond. If they actually cared they could find a way to put the videos up like having them hosted by an individual.

As a note, for linkclump, you need to add an action to be able to shift-select and copy the links.

Also, the doc is view only right now.
My bad, just fixed it!

Here are detailed instructions for setting up LinkClump.

1. Go to https://chrome.google.com/webstore/detail/linkclump/lfpjkncokllnfokkgpkobnkbkmelfefj and install LinkClump.

2. Go to chrome://extensions/, find LinkClump, and select "allow in incognito"

3. Find LinkClump icon next to your address bar. Left click > LinkClump.

4. This will open a new page that looks like this.

5. Click "Add Action" then make the options like this.

Screen_Shot_20170304_at_3.59.04_PM.png

Testing

www.yahoo.com

www.apple.com

www.amazon.com

While pressing the shift key, select the 3 links above, like you're creating a screenshot. You'll see yellow rectangles around the links.

Now paste (cmd-v) into sublime. You should see the three links.
Google Doc creator here. Don't worry about logging in with your gmail account to edit. I've made it editable by anyone with the link to protect your privacy.

https://docs.google.com/document/d/1qQpixjjrPp26-swL_qSRCdj0piqGldfj3V-8eeo8Q5E/edit?usp=sharing

I've created a google doc and added all the webcast links I have (CS 70, EE 16A). Please log in using gmail and add your webcasts. Let's make all the EECS videos accessible to each other!

How to quickly add your webcast links

1. Log into CalCentral > My Academics > Click on course > Go to webcasts > Expand list (keep pressing "show 10 more")

2. Get Linkclump - google chrome extension. Enable the extension for incognito too if needed.

3. While holding shift, select the links of the videos. This will copy them to your clipboard. Then paste into google doc.

***https://chrome.google.com/webstore/detail/linkclump/lfpjkncokllnfokkgpkobnkbkmelfefj

Please let me know if you have any questions at all guys! Happy to help out fellow students, we're all in this together!

So I do agree that this decision sucks, but the government is not forcing Berkeley to take the videos down. The DOJ is asking that Berkeley either make the materials compliant with the ADA or pay a fine. Compliance for all past lecture videos would be in the realm of a few hundred thousand dollars. 

The thing about the ADA that's annoying is that it's mostly implemented and enforced in a zero-sum sort of way. i.e. If X group can't have access, then no one should. On the other hand, I can't think of a better way. If the government never requires businesses to produce content or build physical spaces or software or whatever that are accessible to the disabled, then there's very little incentive for businesses to ever produce such things. Most people, in fact the vast majority, of people do not need wheelchair ramps. They cost an outsized amount to build for the number of users they serve.

In this case we're dealing with closed captions, primarily intended to be used to deaf people. According to basic googling only 3.8 in 1,000 are 'functionally deaf', though quite a bit more have some hearing difficulty, and maybe able-eared individuals that do use captions, there's almost certainly no business case for this. 

To be honest, I don't know what the right answer is - clearly we need to support the deaf, but policies which potentially lead to the removal of an incredibly large body of educational resources seems wrong as well. :(
Will the videos on CalESG be taken down as well? Some of the classes I'm taking this semester (CS 294-112) put their webcasts on that channel.

history.content: I don't believe the department owns or maintains these videos, especially if they're in campus-owned classrooms (outside Soda and Cory). Hopefully someone knows more.

children.subject:
[USEFUL] Links to all EECS webcasts

We've created a google doc*** with links to webcasts for many classes from Fall 2015 to now. 

**https://docs.google.com/document/d/1qQpixjjrPp26-swL_qSRCdj0piqGldfj3V-8eeo8Q5E/edit#heading=h.6z5s73vvfyxg

Please check it out. Also, please contribute to it by adding your own webcasts. You don't need to log in with gmail to preserve your privacy.


I hope this helps everyone out.
Encourage everybody to add links to this doc!

history.content:
Is it possible for the department to grant us students access to webcasts to EECS courses other than those we are enrolled in? They will be taken off Youtube en masse in a few weeks. For those who can't take the course, or will graduate soon, we should have the chance to watch them online. We can still log in using CalNet so there's no problem of random people abusing the videos. 

Not to mention making the videos available to us isn't that hard. You've produced the videos, you've webcasted them, you've offered them to a subset of Berkeley students and now you need to offer the link to a larger set of students. The cost to value ratio of these videos is incredibly low.

And finally, let me ask this: Do you really want Berkeley CS students watching Stanford and MIT professors' webcasts because they have no other choice?

Maybe there are some complexities I don't know about and if so, forgive me. 

---------------------------------------------------------------------

EDIT: Add your webcasts to this link!! See followup at bottom for details.

https://docs.google.com/document/d/1qQpixjjrPp26-swL_qSRCdj0piqGldfj3V-8eeo8Q5E/edit?usp=sharing

How to quickly add your webcast links

1. Log into CalCentral > My Academics > Click on course > Go to webcasts > Expand list (keep pressing "show 10 more")

2. Get Linkclump - google chrome extension. Enable the extension for incognito too if needed.

3. While holding shift, select the links of the videos. This will copy them to your clipboard. Then paste into google doc.

EDIT: Google Doc creator here. Don't worry about logging in with your gmail account to edit. It's editable anonymously, to protect your privacy.
